title: Domain 4.6: Given a scenario, implement and maintain identity and access management.
content:
👥 Provisioning / De-Provisioning User Accounts

  • Provisioning: Create and assign user accounts with the right access.
  • De-provisioning: Disable or remove access immediately when no longer needed—prevents orphaned accounts.

🎚️ Permission Assignments & Implications

Grant only the access needed for a user’s role. Over-permissioning increases the risk of insider threats or misuse.

🧾 Identity Proofing

Verifies that a user is who they claim to be before issuing credentials—often part of onboarding or account recovery.

🌐 Federation

Allows users to access multiple systems across organizations with a single identity (e.g., logging into a partner service with your Google account).

🔑 Single Sign-On (SSO)

User logs in once to access multiple systems—improves usability, but requires strong central security.

🧠 LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol)

Centralized directory of users—used for authentication and querying identity info.

🔓 OAuth (Open Authorization)

Allows third-party apps to access user data without sharing passwords (used by Google, Facebook logins).

📜 SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language)

XML-based framework for exchanging authentication and authorization data—common in enterprise SSO.

🔄 Interoperability

Ensures different identity systems can work together—vital in hybrid or multi-vendor environments.

🧾 Attestation

User or system confirms a specific attribute (e.g., device posture, location) as part of authentication—can feed into access decisions.

🛂 Access Controls

🔐 Mandatory Access Control (MAC)

Strict, centrally enforced access—users can’t change permissions (used in military/government systems).

🧍 Discretionary Access Control (DAC)

Owners of data/resources decide who has access—flexible, but more prone to misuse.

👥 Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)

Access is assigned based on a user's job role—easy to manage across large organizations.

🧾 Rule-Based Access Control

Access is granted based on pre-defined rules (e.g., firewall ACLs, conditions).

🧬 Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)

Access decisions are based on user attributes (e.g., department, clearance level, device type).

⏰ Time-of-Day Restrictions

Access allowed only during certain hours—limits risk during off-hours.

🪪 Least Privilege

Users are given the minimum access needed to do their job—reduces attack surface.

🔒 Multifactor Authentication (MFA)

💡 Implementations

  • 🧬 Biometrics: Fingerprints, face scans, iris recognition—unique to each user.
  • 🔐 Hard/Soft Authentication Tokens:
    • Hard: Physical devices like RSA tokens.
    • Soft: Apps (e.g., Google Authenticator) on phones.
  • 🔑 Security Keys: Hardware-based tokens (e.g., YubiKey) that support standards like FIDO2/WebAuthn.

🧠 Factors

  • 🧠 Something You Know: Passwords, PINs.
  • 📱 Something You Have: Token, smart card, mobile device.
  • 🧬 Something You Are: Biometrics.
  • 📍 Somewhere You Are: Geographic location used to allow/deny access.

🔑 Password Concepts

📏 Password Best Practices

  • 📐 Length: Longer is stronger—12+ characters recommended to withstand brute force attacks.
  • 🔀 Complexity: Use a mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and symbols—avoids easy-to-guess passwords.
  • 🔁 Reuse: Never reuse passwords across accounts—if one gets breached, the others are vulnerable too.
  • ⌛ Expiration: Policies may require regular password changes—but only when necessary (e.g., after compromise).
  • 🧓 Age: Minimum age prevents rapid cycling through password history just to reuse old ones.

🔐 Password Managers

  • Securely store and autofill complex passwords—encourages strong, unique passwords per account.

🛑 Passwordless

  • Uses biometrics, tokens, or other factors instead of passwords—reduces phishing and credential theft risk.

🧰 Privileged Access Management (PAM) Tools

⏱️ Just-in-Time Permissions

  • Temporary elevated access granted only when needed—reduces standing privilege risk.

🏦 Password Vaulting

  • Stores privileged credentials in a secure, encrypted vault—access is logged and audited.

🕓 Ephemeral Credentials

  • One-time or short-lived credentials—automatically expire after use to prevent reuse or abuse.
